Literature Review: Sustainable intensification (SI) has emerged as a crucial approach to address the growing global food demand while minimizing environmental impacts. This literature review focuses on the most promising SI strategies for smallholder agricultural systems, particularly in the Global South, where food security remains a pressing concern.Improved cultivars have consistently demonstrated significant positive impacts on crop yields and farmer incomes across various studies. For instance, Spielman and Smale (2017) reported that the adoption of improved maize varieties in sub-Saharan Africa led to yield increases of 20-30% and income gains of up to 50% for smallholder farmers. Similarly, Evenson and Gollin (2003) found that improved rice varieties contributed to yield gains of 1% per year in Asia during the Green Revolution period.The push-pull system, an agroecological approach, has shown remarkable success in controlling pests and improving yields, particularly in cereal crops. Khan et al. (2014) reported that push-pull technology increased maize yields by 2.5 times compared to monocropping systems in East Africa, while also providing additional benefits such as improved soil fertility and fodder production. Midega et al. (2015) further demonstrated the system's effectiveness in controlling the devastating fall armyworm, reducing crop damage by up to 82.7%.The System of Rice Intensification (SRI) has gained attention as an effective SI strategy for rice production. Uphoff (2012) reviewed multiple studies across 13 countries and found that SRI practices led to average yield increases of 47% compared to conventional methods, while using 40% less water. Gathorne-Hardy et al. (2016) reported that SRI not only improved yields but also reduced greenhouse gas emissions by up to 40% compared to flooded rice systems.While these strategies have shown promise, barriers to adoption remain significant. Access to improved seeds and inputs is a major constraint for many smallholder farmers. Shiferaw et al. (2014) identified lack of credit, limited extension services, and inadequate market access as key factors limiting the adoption of improved crop varieties in sub-Saharan Africa. Similarly, Glover (2011) found that labor requirements and risk aversion were significant barriers to SRI adoption in many contexts.The potential for scaling these successful SI strategies is considerable. Improved cultivars have already reached a significant proportion of smallholder farmers in many regions. Walker and Alwang (2015) estimated that improved varieties of major food crops were planted on 35% of cultivated area in sub-Saharan Africa by 2010, with even higher rates in some countries. However, there is still substantial room for growth, particularly for newer, climate-resilient varieties.Push-pull systems and SRI have shown promising results but currently have more limited reach. Pickett et al. (2014) reported that push-pull technology had been adopted by over 125,000 smallholder farmers in East Africa by 2014, with potential for much wider adoption given its effectiveness and relatively low input requirements. For SRI, Styger and Uphoff (2016) estimated that the practice had spread to over 10 million farmers across more than 60 countries by 2016, demonstrating its adaptability to diverse contexts.To overcome adoption barriers and scale these successful SI strategies, several approaches have been proposed. Participatory plant breeding and varietal selection have shown promise in developing and disseminating improved cultivars that meet farmers' needs and preferences (Ceccarelli and Grando, 2007). For push-pull systems, farmer-to-farmer learning and demonstration plots have been effective in promoting adoption (Murage et al., 2015). In the case of SRI, adaptive research and flexible implementation guidelines have facilitated its spread to diverse agroecological contexts (Uphoff et al., 2011).Policy interventions also play a crucial role in scaling SI strategies. Jayne et al. (2018) argue that public investments in rural infrastructure, agricultural research, and extension services are essential for creating an enabling environment for SI adoption. Additionally, Pingali (2012) emphasizes the importance of developing inclusive value chains and market linkages to incentivize smallholder farmers to adopt improved technologies and practices.In conclusion, improved cultivars, push-pull systems, and SRI emerge as the most promising SI strategies for smallholder agricultural systems based on consistent evidence of positive impacts on yields and farmer incomes. While significant barriers to adoption persist, these strategies have considerable potential to scale and contribute to meeting Sustainable Development Goals 1 and 2 by 2030. Future research should focus on context-specific adaptations of these strategies, innovative approaches to overcoming adoption barriers, and effective policy mechanisms to support widespread implementation.
